channel.title: Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog
channel.description: Travel & Photo blog of my travels

item.title: Morocco 2015: 2/3 gorges; dades & todra
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
My second leg of the trip went up Dades Gorge, and down Todra gorge. In between is tizi n ouano, a lonely pass at around 2900 meters. Moving away from Boumalne dades on a grey day (one of two on the whole trip). Greenery from the river, otherwise the stream of villages blended in with […]

The post Morocco 2015: 2/3 gorges; dades & todra appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Morocco 2015: 1/3 Crossing the high atlas
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Yet again I’ve gone cycle touring in Moroccos Atlas mountains. I took four weeks off work, spent two and a half cycling, and then a week at a co-working/co-living space. Before leaving I tweeked my bike a little. New suspension saddle stem, 40mm tires. Both made riding the pistes (unsealed roads typical in the Atlas […]

The post Morocco 2015: 1/3 Crossing the high atlas appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Albania
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Albania is on the Adriatic coast, bordered by Montenegro to the north, Greece to the south, and Kosovo and Macedonia to the east. My first stop was in the historic town of Shkoder. Like Ulcinj in southern Montenegro it has historically fallen between control of Montenegro and Albania. Being at the mouth of a large […]

The post Albania appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Mountainous Montenegro
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Montenegro was very scenic and a pleasure to cycle through. Not much traffic for most of my route and easy to wild camp. I reached the border up in the mountains after a very long climb, the border guard was friendly and we had a typical exchange: “what is your job” “I’m a programmer” “It’s […]

The post Mountainous Montenegro appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Kosovo continued
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
I stayed four days in Prishtina (capital of Kosovo) having quite a fun time. There’s not too much to see as it’s mainly an administrative city full of NGO types. I met a bunch of interesting people though and ended up making quite a big tour around Kosovo too, first going down to Prizren in […]

The post Kosovo continued appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Serbia to Kosovo
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
From Sarajevo I headed towards Serbia to ride to Kosovo. I wasn’t in Serbia long, just a couple of days. I avoided the big cities and just visited a monastery. I’m now in Pristina the capital of Kosovo. The republic of Srepska, one of three? main areas in Bosnia & Herzegovina, which one fairly radical […]

The post Serbia to Kosovo appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Sarajevo and southern Bosnia & Herzegovina
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
It was good to finally leave Mostar and enjoy some cycling again. I headed towards the capital Sarajevo and had some great weather and scenery to ride through. Lots of Mosques dotted around. The Balkans are home to lots of muslims, mainly as a result of the Ottoman empire expanding into europe in the 1300s. […]

The post Sarajevo and southern Bosnia & Herzegovina appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Mostar for the week
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Met some Jesuits walking from Poland to Rome on the road. They were super friendly, covering around 30km a day, and had an audience with the pope arranged. Nice rolling hills continue in Bosnia, with lots of ‘big’ green landscapes. Cycling from Split in Croatia to Mostar in Bosnia & Herzegovina I started thinking it […]

The post Mostar for the week appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Coastal Croatia
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Not long after the lakes national park I bumpted into Dylan, a french Swiss, also bike touring and heading in the same direction. He was also looking for hilly routes so we rode together for a couple of days, first over some mountains to the coast, then along a little towards Zadar where I left […]

The post Coastal Croatia appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Into Croatia – Zagreb and Plitvicka national park
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Just before the border with Croatia I met Tyler, a Canadian who after breaking with his girlfriend in Austria bought a crappy bike for €50 and decided to cycle to Greece. He was a bit nuts but quite nice. We spent a day or so cycling together. He had no maps or maintenance stuff for […]

The post Into Croatia – Zagreb and Plitvicka national park appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Budapest and beyond
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
This summer I got two months of work to travel, I planned to fly to Budapest to tour around the Balkans, continuing a previous bike trip I did from Stockholm to Budapest a few years ago. I took my bike the usual way on the plane and that was fine, but had managed to damage […]

The post Budapest and beyond appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Atlas mountains Morocco 2014
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
After a year in Denmark since the trip in Africa and northern Europe I went back to one of my favorite places I’ve ever bike toured, the Atlas mountains in Morocco. Starting and ending in Marrakesh (via a cheap flight from Copenhagen) we biked for about ten days, and then had a few days in […]

The post Atlas mountains Morocco 2014 appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Life in Denmark; an interlude to the bike trip
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We have been in Denmark for around six weeks now. We decided to stop and settle for some time, I’ll stay here until spring at least before continuing. Staying with Julies family, and enjoying Denmark over the winter. My plan is to save up some money and enjoy being here settled in a normal routine […]

The post Life in Denmark; an interlude to the bike trip appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Denmark: Tønder to Roskilde, easy flat cycling and a family welcome
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Our first stop in Denmark was Tønder where Julie’s granny lives and family are from. It was just a few kilometres over the border from Germany but straight away quite different – lots of red and white everything; signs, building colour schemes, and obviously flags. We were excited to be in Denmark, we’d already decided […]

The post Denmark: Tønder to Roskilde, easy flat cycling and a family welcome appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Germany
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We previously cycled in Germany two years ago when going from Sweden to Hungary, then we passed through the north east, this time we’d go through the north west. The weather is colder and the landscape not as interesting. Our route took us across a few large rivers which we crossed by small boats, most […]

The post Germany appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Netherlands Amsterdam and more cycle lanes cold temperatures and German expectations
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We made it to Amsterdam with my torn rear wheel still intact, but crack getting bigger. We planed to stay a few days while seeing the sites and finding me a new rear wheel to go with my new front wheel recently purchased in Paris. Lizard sculptures. Dutch sense of humour? Dutch wooden clogs “klompen”. […]

The post Netherlands Amsterdam and more cycle lanes cold temperatures and German expectations appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Netherlands and blue skies
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Nederlands, a country with more bikes than people, has a good reputation for cycling. There are cycle routes absolutely everywhere, usually a dedicated road beside the car road just for bikes/people and rarely just a lane on the road. Cycling on the road isn’t allowed when there’s a bike route beside, which has gotten quite […]

The post Netherlands and blue skies appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Belgium
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Our cycle in Belgium saw the cold and heavy rain continue that we’d had through north west France and Luxembourg. We took quite a direct route towards the border with Nederlands at Mastricht passing through Liege but no other main Belgian city. The landscape was rolling in the south and would have been very nice […]

The post Belgium appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Luxembourg
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
A very small country we spent two nights in Luxembourg after accidentally going through a slither of Belgium first (our route from Paris was a bit all over the place). We didn’t notice an official border, just a sign indicating the different speed limits. Our warm shower host in Luxembourg couldn’t host us until two […]

The post Luxembourg appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: North east France; Paris to Luxembourg, bad weather and a general rant about my bike
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Day 209 – 10,668 km The cycle from Paris to Luxembourg took four or five days in which it rained everyday. We cycled around 100km each day taking an indirect route on fairly quiet roads and found wild camping spots easily each night in wooded areas. We stopped every couple of days in a mcdonalds […]

The post North east France; Paris to Luxembourg, bad weather and a general rant about my bike appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Paris, broken wheel
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We’ve stayed three nights in Paris instead of two. My front rim has broke, which after doing 30,000 km is good going, and convenient in a city full of bike shops. Picked up a 700cc double walled 36 spoke wheel (previous was 32, fully built with hub) for €45. Could of toured nine days with […]

The post Paris, broken wheel appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Cherbourg to Paris et d’autres directions
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Nice cycle routes took us the first part of the way from Cherbourg to Paris, one or two days at least. After that we were on roads, mostly nice quiet country routes with little traffic. Taking such a route added a hundred plus kilometres to the 330 km Google estimate but made for a nice […]

The post Cherbourg to Paris et d’autres directions appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: England and our onward route for Europe
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Our flight left South Africa in the evening, we got to London the next night after a stop over in Dubai through the day. As we arrived in Gatwick airport in the evening, we slept there until leaving the next morning. We didn’t have a map for England and from google maps could just see […]

The post England and our onward route for Europe appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: A short cycle in South Africa to Johannesburg
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We passed through the border from Botswana to South Africa easily, our last in Africa. The immigration official for SA was very friendly, and in disbelief at our journey and passport visa trail, came out to look at our bikes and ask questions (what about the lions?) despite a growing queue inside of people waiting […]

The post A short cycle in South Africa to Johannesburg appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Botswana
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We arrived in Botswana not expecting much difference from Zambia and soon realised otherwise. The country is much more developed, even in rural areas, and a pleasure to be in. The border we entered in from Zambia at Kazungula is a special ‘quadripoint’ border where four countries meet, so of course crossing it had to […]

The post Botswana appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Victoria falls in Zambia
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
In Lusaka we booked our flights from SA onwards, buying several weeks in advance was far cheaper than waiting until we got to SA but meant we were now on a schedule. From Chipata to Lusaka the scenery was very bland. We met other cyclists who told us how sparse it would become. We started […]

The post Victoria falls in Zambia appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Into Zambia; Koreans, bland landscapes, hills and a few more travellers
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Day 164 – 8,642 km We enjoyed a nice cycle into Zambia to the first town called Chipata. The roads were nice and quiet, noticeably different from Malawi where people were everywhere and constantly begging for money from the road side. Came across a big Spar supermarket and enjoyed cool fruit juice yoghurt and other […]

The post Into Zambia; Koreans, bland landscapes, hills and a few more travellers appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Malawi
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We entered Malawi in the afternoon, and covered 50 km to the first town (Karonga) where we stayed in a rest house near lake Malawi. After sunset the frogs/toads came to say hello and I had to chase a handful out of our room. Funny at first but after a few hours, typical Africa nonsense. […]

The post Malawi appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: South west Tanzania to Malawi: Mountains national parks and
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
The first few hundreds kilometres from Dar es Salaam were quite dull, more interesting was my new food thermos fixed tent and replacement stove. Fresh pineapple and papaya (pau pau here), yum. Ugali, not so yummy. The scenery became more interesting on the way to Morogoro, after several hundred kilometers. Eighty kilometres later we entered […]

The post South west Tanzania to Malawi: Mountains national parks and appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Dar es Salaam
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
After three weeks on Zanzibar the parcel we’d been waiting on arrived, courtesy of my sister back in Britain – Thanks. Some mechanical parts, new touring gear, and the pleasant surprise of real shortbread. After previously paying £140 to collect the parcel in Nairobi, paying nothing this time was a lesson learned. For anybody interested, […]

The post Dar es Salaam appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Pole pole, a slow end
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Some more pictures from Zanzibar: Net mending this week: Youngster cycling on the beach. There are few child bikes in Africa, with most riding a big diamond frame. Trees we swam around, in low and high tide: Worrying signs. Woman collect shellfish (Julie thinks muscles): Of for another swim, not the nicest beach we visited. […]

The post Pole pole, a slow end appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Pole pole continued, more slow days
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We had two options for the parcel before, send it to Malawi and hope my rack held up, or wait here and let it come to us. After several months cyling through the wilds of Africa, we thought we’d enjoy the relative luxury here some more. I took on a small web project which I’ve […]

The post Pole pole continued, more slow days appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Pole Pole, a holiday on the slow island
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We came to Zanzibar to spend three or so days. It’s a small island with few roads to cycle. It’s now been nearly three weeks we’ve stayed, still we aren’t rushing to leave either. We’ve lazed around in Stone town seeing the sights (about two of ten), but enjoyed the people and atmosphere. Zanzibar is […]

The post Pole Pole, a holiday on the slow island appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Zanzibar
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
It is today our 16th day on Zanzibar. It feels as if we have been on a holiday, we have been off the bikes and out of the touring-rhythm and stayed long enough at this hotel to feel at home. It was not the plan to stay this long. When we first arrived it felt […]

The post Zanzibar appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Calm coastal Tanzania: Islam, hills, trails and monotony
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
June 9th – 14th Day 115 – 5814 km After a nice nights camping in the bush we carried on along an unsealed road from Tanga to Pangani. Twenty minutes into the ride and the bumpy road proved too much for my weary rack.. Now both rear supports had snapped, and I was out of […]

The post Calm coastal Tanzania: Islam, hills, trails and monotony appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Palms and black tea, coast bound
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
June 7th – 9th Day 110 – 5408 km Over several slow days of wind we passed through the mountains south of Moshi and started to reach Korogwe, where we’d turn east to the coast. The landscape changed quite quickly. We’d seen palm trees for a while but now we’d left the open planes of […]

The post Palms and black tea, coast bound appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Mountains sickness wind and punctures
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
2nd – 6th of June Day 107 – 5236 km We stayed two comfortable nights at our warm showers host in Arusha. I tweeked my bike a little, fitting a new chain and jockey wheel. We both ate well with our host cooking some fantastic meals which I had seconds thirds and fourths. Coming away […]

The post Mountains sickness wind and punctures appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Across to Tanzania – Namanga border, mountain views, child shepherds and tasty tea
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
A hundred straight forward kilometres took us to Namanga, the border town with Tanzania. We passed nice scenery on the way but nothing too special. Stopping at cafes in the occasional village for nice milky chai was the highlight for me. The scenery reminded me a little of the Ethiopian Kenyan border, with lots of […]

The post Across to Tanzania – Namanga border, mountain views, child shepherds and tasty tea appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Nairobi – Camping couch surfing parcels and delays
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We planned to stay with a couch-surfer/warm-shower in Nairobi, but having arranged to stay several weeks previous had only confirmed it a day before Nairobi. Our host was away in England, but his wife would happily host us if she was around we were told, and given her number and rough location in Nairobi. This […]

The post Nairobi – Camping couch surfing parcels and delays appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Equatorial cycling in Kenya, Hells gate national park, the rift valley and Nairobi
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Julie The first of Kenya; Mount Kenya, national parks, some great days cycling I think we both agree that Kenya is one of our favourite countries so far. After the truck experience getting to Isiolo, arriving we were tired and dusty. We stayed two nights, got a puncture on Sam’s back tire fixed, washed a […]

The post Equatorial cycling in Kenya, Hells gate national park, the rift valley and Nairobi appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Moyale truck
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Entering Kenya was nice and simple, and as it meant leaving Ethiopia, hugely satisfying. We tried to spend our last Birr and got a crap meal with, now typical, crap Ethiopian service and half our order missing. Moyale is a town spread over the border and each side is different. The friendly Kenyan immigration officer […]

The post Moyale truck appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Out of Addis
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
The morning of leaving Addis, I lost one of my shoes that I had left outside the door. Later It was found again but this was after a neighbouring dog had chewed it to even less of a shoe than it was at that point. When Gina, the warmshower host that we stayed with found […]

The post Out of Addis appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Addis Ababa; awaiting Kenya visa, hospitality, weight gain
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We’ve now branched out from Couch surfing and have started using a website called Warm showers (basically couch-surfing for cyclists). Our hosts here in Addis are a lovely English-German couple who live in the German Embassy compound. The embassy compound land was gifted to Germany from Haille Sallese a long time ago and it a […]

The post Addis Ababa; awaiting Kenya visa, hospitality, weight gain appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Ethiopian shortcuts; hills, altitude, hotels, churches, buses, and our first robbery
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
As you’ll have gathered from the last few posts Julie published, we’ve made it to Addis. We spent five nights in Gondar relaxing and not feeling too rushed to continue. The roads and people had been tough hard work and didn’t leave us raring to get back on them. Despite changing hotel four times, staying […]

The post Ethiopian shortcuts; hills, altitude, hotels, churches, buses, and our first robbery appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: A bus to Addis
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
After two nights camping in the garden of a friendly Ethiopian couch-surfer, his house on a hill overlooking Lalibela, excellent views and with a very friendly dog keeping us company, we decided it was time to move on. We were both feeling tired of cycling in the conditions we had had getting to Lalibela, with […]

The post A bus to Addis appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Lalibela
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
On the morning of the 26th we had just a short 30 km cycle to get to the town from where we would take a bus to Lalibela. It would be just 60 km but the road is unpaved so I was glad we had the option of taking a bus. We found a minibus, […]

The post Lalibela appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: On the Chinese road
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
We were on the road at 7 am the next morning. After about 27 km we turned east onto the ‘Chinese Road’ (the Chinese built it) towards Lalibela and again the landscape became hilly. The grades were not too crazy but they were very long, and I find that when a hill is very long […]

The post On the Chinese road appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Leaving Gondar
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
After five days in Gondar, four different hotels, and time to rest and drink lots of water, we were ready to cycle again. Before leaving the city we had a coffee at a small roadside cafe, which most little towns we pass have, often a coffee lady cooking the coffee in a traditional long-necked ceramic […]

The post Leaving Gondar appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Gondar
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
We were happy to arrive in Gondar to have a few days rest. The first night we stayed in a hotel that to our standards was a fancy hotel with en-suite bathroom, tv and wireless internet. The next day we moved to a different hotel in the centre of the city and close to the […]

The post Gondar appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Climbing into the Ethiopian highlands; hills heat children and spectacular scenery
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
April 16th – 17th : 149km Day 55 – 3024 km Population and poverty An average Ethiopian woman has five children. In the last fifty years the population of Africa has doubled, except in Ethiopia where it’s tripled (despite going through several famines – some killing as many as one million people). We see children […]

The post Climbing into the Ethiopian highlands; hills heat children and spectacular scenery appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Enter Ethiopia
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
April 15th : 103 km Day 57 – 3174 km Leaving Sudan was straightforward but problematic. We had to pay a departure tax of around £25 for not registering within three days of arrival. We did register in Wadi Halfa (before getting of the boat and even setting foot on Sudan), and showed the idiot […]

The post Enter Ethiopia appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Sudanese
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We’ve enjoyed meeting so many Sudanese, and could have met a thousand more if we’d had the time, they’re some of the friendliest people I’ve encountered. Here are some pictures of the warm people of Sudan.

The post Sudanese appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: South out of Sudan
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
April 10th – 14th : 542km Day 54 – 2921 km Khartoum to Wad Medani If you look at a satalite picture of Africa you’ll see the Sahara ends in Khartoum, the area immediately south is called the Sahel and geographically marks the line between desert and sub-saharan Africa. In Sudan this is the bread […]

The post South out of Sudan appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Khartoum – new friends, an Ethiopian visa, and the museum
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We meet Sekiji in Khartoum city centre who, with the help of his GPS, cycled us through the night crowds of Khartoum to our couch-surfing hosts apartment. The city was very dark but full of life noise and shadows. On arrival we enjoyed a well needed shower before a lovely big meal (one of the […]

The post Khartoum – new friends, an Ethiopian visa, and the museum appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: South to Khartoum; Begrawiya pyramids and some more days cycling the Nile
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
April 5th – 7th : 349 km Day 47 – 2378 km We stayed the night in Atbara enjoying a hot shower, internet, and use of a kettle for a night. Atbara is a transport hub town which links the Nile with the red sea. We stocked up on tonnes of supplies at shops with […]

The post South to Khartoum; Begrawiya pyramids and some more days cycling the Nile appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Meroe to Atbara: Across the Bayuda desert
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
April 1st – 4th : 345 km Day 44 – 2029 km We had camped at the Karima pyramids the night before, where Karima is the name of the town on the Niles west bank, and Meroe is the towns name on the east bank. Maybe before the bridge was built they were quite separate, […]

The post Meroe to Atbara: Across the Bayuda desert appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Dongola to Karima; a thirsty desert cycle to the Karima and Meroe pyramids
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
March 30th – 31st : 210 km Day 40 – 1684 km Dongola We camped just short of Dongola with the plan to ride in early and get supplies before it got too hot. After Dongola we’d cycle 200 km across the desert to Karima, so we needed a couple days worth of food. Sudan […]

The post Dongola to Karima; a thirsty desert cycle to the Karima and Meroe pyramids appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: A hospitable farm
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
March 29th : 131 km Day 38 – 1474 km After a couple of fast days cycling through northern Sudan we were keen to see our first ‘sight’. A fifty metre tall mud temple which you could climb to the top. Unfortunately we never found it.. A lot of Sudans sights are very well hidden, […]

The post A hospitable farm appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Cycling south into Sudan from Wadi Halfa
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
March 26th – 28th : 304 km Day 37 – 1343 km Sudan was instantly different to Egypt. The scenery was pretty similar, a sandy hot desert, but the people and atmosphere quite apart. We’d left Egypt of the middle east and entered Sudan of Africa. We cycled a peaceful couple of kilometres into Wadi […]

The post Cycling south into Sudan from Wadi Halfa appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: A busy boat from Aswan to Wadi Halfa
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Despite two brand new roads linking Sudan and Egypt on their 1275 km border, bureaucracy has kept them closed leaving the weekly ferry the only overland route. We’d missed the first chance at the boat due to a delay in getting our visas, and having seen people with tickets for the ferry being turned away the […]

The post A busy boat from Aswan to Wadi Halfa appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Whiling a week away in Aswan
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We spent a week extra in Aswan before successfully leaving on the boat. All in all, about twelve days. We stayed in the city but spent some time seeing nearby Nubian villages, a monastery in the desert, and enjoyed the locals. Our hotel was £2 a night, including breakfast. There was a roof top terrace […]

The post Whiling a week away in Aswan appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Get visa for Sudan in Aswan Egypt and ticket for boat to Wadi Halfa
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
This post details our process of getting a tourist visa for Sudan in Aswan in Egypt and then the boat ticket for Aswan to Wadi Halfa and is here to serve as a reference to any other traveller looking for up to date information. This was in March 2013. View Sudan visa and boat ticket […]

The post Get visa for Sudan in Aswan Egypt and ticket for boat to Wadi Halfa appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: No Sudan, stuck in Aswan
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
While in Aswan we met two other cyclists. A German and French man who’d been cycling for some time separately but joined up in Sinai Egypt. Also trying to get a Sudanese visa was a Japanese guy who was travelling overland (but not by bike). We arrived in Aswan four days ahead of the boat […]

The post No Sudan, stuck in Aswan appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Luxor to Aswan
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
March 14th : 238 kmDay 23 – 984 km We left Luxor at ten am, after some sightseeing and dollar hunting. The cycling was pleasant, but the heat made it quite tedious. We cycled through farming areas, and beside irrigation canals for most of the day, with little change in the scenery at all. Stopping […]

The post Luxor to Aswan appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Luxor
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We spent three nights in Luxor staying in a friendly – and largely empty – little hotel hidden down some back streets away from the nile. Luxor is the worst place we’ve ever been for hustlers, very hard to enjoy being outside here. Everybody wants to sell you a boat, horse, bike or taxi ride. […]

The post Luxor appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Cairo to Luxor
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
March 9th : 280 km Day 19 – 746 km From Cairo to Luxor day one It seems that very much happened in the three days it took us to get to Luxor, and of course nothing went as we could have imagined, little detours and short-cuts that we never planned or could have foreseen. […]

The post Cairo to Luxor appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Sightseeing in Cairo: Giza pyramids, Islamic Cairo, Coptic Cairo, Tahrir square
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Giza Pyramids After a day at the Egyptian museum we were ready for the Pyramids. A very cheap metro (£0.10) plus a half an hour walk and a bizarre taxi ride later we were there. They sit just on the outskirts of Cairo, and mark very sharply where compact city becomes desolate desert. We walked […]

The post Sightseeing in Cairo: Giza pyramids, Islamic Cairo, Coptic Cairo, Tahrir square appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Cairo Chaos
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Traffic Cairo is a lively city to say the least. My view of an ancient Islamic city linking the middle east with north Africa was quickly replaced with a more contemporary reality: it’s a mega-city in the desert with little order and lots of rubbish. We rode into the city from the round about we […]

The post Cairo Chaos appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Cairo now
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We stayed one night in the first hotel, it was very nice, but a bit classy for us. Another hostel not too far away for £3.25 a night each agreed with our budget very well. We have a double room which opens onto a communal roof garden, plants – and cats – everywhere. A little […]

The post Cairo now appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: To Cairo
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
February 26th : 69 km Day 6 – 464 km After refilling our water bag and buying the same date and fig rolls at the same services we’d past the day before our detour we set of on the coastal road north again. This part of the coast had a huge wind farm on one […]

The post To Cairo appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: St Anthonys monastery
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
February 23rd – February 24th : 144 km Day 5 – 395 km The monastery Half way from Hurghada to Cairo we took a detour west into the desert to visit St Anthonys monastery. One of two Coptic Christian monasteries in the area, and the first monastery in the world. It was started in 1700 […]

The post St Anthonys monastery appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Hurghada north
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
20th February – 22nd February : 251 km Day 3 – 251 km The flight into Hurghada passed over some great landscapes, all looking hot dry rough barren and inhospitable, but teasing adventure new horizons the unfamiliar and uncertain. Excitement aside, we first had to get through the airport and get on the road; get […]

The post Hurghada north appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: France to Egypt
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
We spent two weeks in the village of Engravies, with my mum, doing some odd jobs but mainly enjoying a carefree pace of life. We had some short walks and cycles, and enjoyed the wintered scenery. The cheapest way on to Cairo for us was via Switzerland, and so at four o clock in the […]

The post France to Egypt appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Organising what I’m taking
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Gear Today I’ve gone through all the stuff I’m taking, making sure it’s all there, and arranging it all as I’ll put it in my panniers. Lots of stuff indeed: This post is more for the bike-tourers, interested in what we’re taking. I plan to do a re-post every 10,000 kms or so on how […]

The post Organising what I’m taking appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Getting to France
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
We had some nice days in Crewkerne getting fattened up with many nice meals made by Sams family, a good ending to the UK before going to France. On the Monday we got a train from Crewkerne to London. We arrived in the early afternoon and decided to cycle to Heathrow for our flight to […]

The post Getting to France appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Glasgow to Crewkerne
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
After two days staying with our friend Peter, and enjoying a last Scottish breakfast, we left Glasgow in appropriately wet weather. My bike is certainly the heaviest it’s ever been, but on the flat roads this means lots of momentum, so not all bad. The Caledonian sleeper from Glasgow to London was great, I’d highly […]

The post Glasgow to Crewkerne appeared first on Sam Thomson Cycle touring/travel Photo Blog.

item.title: Onwards
item.dc:creator: Julie
item.description:
We move out of the flat tomorrow morning. Aside from the furniture that was here already, all that is left are things that we will take with us, our bikes, equipment, clothes etc. (maybe Sam will later upload his full packing list, nicely organized, detailed with the weight of every item plus maybe some photos). […]
